definition:
A sequence $\{x_i\}$ is said to converge linearly to $x^*$ if there is a
constant $1>c>0$ such that $||x_{i+1}-x^*|| \leq c ||x_i -x^*||$ for all
$i>N$ for some natural number $N>0$.

An alternative definition is that
$||x_{i+1}-x_i|| \leq c ||x_i - x_{i-1} ||$ for all $i$.

Notice that if $N=1$, then by iterating the first inequality we have
$$||x_{i+1}-x^*|| \leq c^i ||x_1 -x^*||.$$ That is, the error decreases
exponentially with the index $i$.

If the inequality holds for all $c>0$ then we say that the sequence
$\{x_i\}$ has *superlinear convergence*.
